thread.title: Bolton says Shelby charter allows commission to hire him as special counsel
thread.title_full: Bolton says Shelby charter allows commission to hire him as special counsel

author: Linda A. Moore
title: Bolton says Shelby charter allows commission to hire him as special counsel
text:
Julian Bolton , an attorney and former Shelby County Commissioner, said his research has found that the county commission can hire its own attorney â€” meaning it can hire him.
Bolton submitted a "Summary of Legal Issues and Brief of Authorities Regarding Special Counsel" to commission chairman Terry Roland Wednesday, asserting that the commission can appoint special counsel that reports directly to the chairman and would maintain attorney-client confidentiality with the commission.
"We can hire our own counsel and I'm going to hire him," Roland said. "We've already done a letter of engagement. He's supposed to meet with county attorney to determine the rate of pay and all that. We'll have our first executive session Monday."
The hiring of special counsel does not necessarily mean for a special project, he said.
County attorney Ross Dyer would not comment on Bolton's assessment Thursday, while county Mayor Mark Luttrell referred questions to Dyer.
Dyer has consistently pointed to the county charter, which states that the county attorney is the "chief counsel" for the county and "shall act as legal advisor" to the mayor and commission.
Bolton, who also wouldn't comment, asserts in his brief that chief counsel does not mean "sole counsel."
"Based on the portions on charter that Julian pointed out, I believe that the commission is fully within its rights to hire any staff it needs to do its job, including legal counsel," said Commissioner Heidi Shafer .
The move to hire Bolton comes as tensions rise between some Republican commissioners, including Roland and Shafer, and the Republican mayor's administration. The county attorney is appointed by the mayor and approved by the commission.
Commissioner Van Turne r, an attorney and a Democrat, believes that there is a way for the commission and the administration to reach a compromise, which may hinge on whether Bolton is called special counsel or a policy advisor who "happens to be an attorney."
"I believe there is space for a reasonable resolution outside of court intervention. However, I believe both parties have to be willing to give and take and hopefully this can be mediated," Turner said.
If that doesn't happen, an appeal to the courts won't result in a quick solution.
And at that point, he said, the commission might choose to consider "a different outlook on this whole notion of having special counsel."
